conclusion: The graph plots 1 / v (vertical axis) against the displacement x (horizontal axis).
The plotted line rises as x increases; therefore 1 / v increases with x.
If 1 / v increases, the speed v itself must be decreasing (because v = 1 / (1 / v) and the reciprocal of a growing positive quantity becomes smaller).
The particle is moving in one fixed direction (straight line) and its speed is getting smaller.
A decreasing speed in a fixed direction means the magnitude of velocity is falling.
Hence the acceleration vector is opposite to the velocity vector.
The particle is decelerating (it has an acceleration opposite to the direction of motion).
